qas.question: What are a couple other ways to write countout?

answers.text: when a wrestler is out of the ring long enough for the referee to count to ten

qas.question: What will some wrestlers do to take advantage of the countout?

answers.text: sliding in the ring, and immediately sliding back out

qas.question: What is the trick of sliding in and then back out of the ring called?

context: A countout (alternatively <a0_0>"count-out" or "count out"<a0_0/>) happens <a1_0>when a wrestler is out of the ring long enough for the referee to count to ten<a1_0/> (twenty in some promotions) and thus disqualified. The count is broken and restarted when a wrestler in the ring exits the ring. Playing into this, some wrestlers will "milk" the count by <a2_0>sliding in the ring, and immediately sliding back out<a2_0/>. As they were technically inside the ring for a split second before exiting again, it is sufficient to restart the count. This is often referred to by commentators as "<a3_0>breaking the count.<a3_0/>" Heels often use this tactic in order to buy themselves more time to catch their breath, or to attempt to frustrate their babyface opponents.
